title: How to get admission in Berklee College of Music? What's the criteria - Quora

response.answer_text: I believe the admission criteria is posted on their website. Berklee now requires a performance audition and interview for admission. You can actually get the most updated edition requirements from their website. Berklee College of Music One suggestion, though. If you’ve never taken any formal music instruction before, I would suggest that you take some classes at a local community college near you. Or, at the very least, find a private instructor to work with for a period of time. The work can be very difficult if one is in used to study music in a formal environment. In addition, Berklee is very expensive. So, if you’re going to spend that kind of money to go to music school, you should at the very least prepare yourself adequately so that you can take optimal advantage of the opportunity.

If you’re seriously considering Berklee, the formal criteria can be found in the acceptance literature in the application and on the website. From an insider perspective: • a good amount of skill…someone who has done (or is willing to do) their homework. • an open mind • good represntative for the school (personality, demeanor, etc.) In my personal experience however, the biggest one is this: POTENTIAL. Are you someone that can learn, grow, be molded, but also break the mold and make your own? Are you a worthy investment? So yes, be good. Work your butt off before you get there and while you’re there. But in my personal experience, they want someone who will find their Berklee experience invaluable because the school was able to unlock a whole lot of potential that the student (and others) may not have even known was there. It’s abstract, I know, but I think it holds true. They will invest in those individuals who seem to have a lot of potential. They’re not always looking for perfection.

Graduating 2017- When I went through the whole admission process back in 2013–14ish there was the basic admissions application (remember this is a college). There was also an audition and interview. Berklee College of Music >side panel >Admissions Once and if you get accepted you need to figure out your plan of attack to pay the first semester. Scholarships - Scholarships - Grants - Scholarships try avoiding taking loans at all costs if FAFSA isn’t cutting it. It’s also good to have a pre-existing knowledge of music theory (you can test out and save money that way) You can also transfer credits from previous college institutions to cover your liberal arts or take the CLEPs (make sure you get the list of what classes they are allowed to take- there is also a cap off of how many credits can be transferred) If I didn’t have the GI Bill and Yellow Ribbon Program I honestly would not have gone. Even with the Berklee Achievement Scholarship and everything I had to cough up a couple of grand. Every college is the same in regards to it’s what you make of the educational experience. I know so many of my colleagues who graduated with me who are back in their hometown trying to figure out life. I also know some of my colleagues going after their musical passions. Also remember with the increase of Berklee alumnus, there is not a necessary increase of jobs in this industry- you need to be creative and pave your career so that you can ultimately do the one thing you love and cannot live without.

while Berklee is an elite institution, it is also a private, family run business. So the truth is, if you can write a check for the full tuition, you will get in. However, if you require financial assistance, you need to have musical ability equal to the amount of money you’re short. That being said, Berklee was the best thing that I ever did. It gave me knowledge, context, experience and a network I draw upon to this day. And I left there in 1972!
